headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Nashville Officers Speak Out; Trump Faces 35 Felony Counts; Michael Bamberger is Interviewed about Tiger Woods. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: All right, so, for the first time we're now hearing from the police officers, the very brave officers who stopped that school shooter at Nashville's Covenant School. Last week's attack at the private Christian school left six people dead, three of them nine-year-old students, three of them adults, and investigators have also seized new evidence from inside of the shooter's home, including a suicide note and even more guns.Our Isabel Rosales reports. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COMMANDER DAYTON WHEELER, MIDTOWN HILLS PRECINCT
utterances.sentences: March. 27th is a day that I will never forget.ISABEL ROSALES, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice over):  Fourteen minutes of terror inside the Covenant School coming to an end -

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's go!

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: At the hands of metropolitan Nashville police officers.

utterances.speaker: OFFICER REX ENGELBERT, RESPONDED TO DEADLY SHOOTING AT THE COVENANT SCHOOL
utterances.sentences: I really had no business being where I was.

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: Officer Rex Engelbert says it was by chance he was near the school, outside his precinct, when the first 911 call came in.

utterances.speaker: ENGELBERT
utterances.sentences: You can call it fate or God or whatever you want, but, there - I can't count on both my hands the irregularities that put me in that position.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Metro police!

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: Blaring alarms and chaos. Engelbert's body camera capturing the moments a group of five officers raced down hallways decorated with children's artwork.

utterances.speaker: WHEELER
utterances.sentences: We began to receive gunfire from a second floor window as officers were inside searching for that individual. ROSALES

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Door. Door. With me.

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: This is their desperate search for a shooter, armed with three guns and showing no signs of stopping. Along the way, grim discoveries.SGT. JEFF MATHES, RESPONDED TO DEADLY SHOOING AT THE COVENANT SCHOOL: All of us stepped over a victim. I, to this day, don't know how I did that morally. But training is what kicked in.

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: They followed their senses. An acrid odor.

utterances.speaker: MATHES
utterances.sentences: The smell of gunpowder was in the air.

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: Then, a chilling sound.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We heard another shot and that's what told us that the shooter was to our right.

utterances.speaker: MATHES
utterances.sentences: Once we got near the shooter, and the shooter was neutralized.

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: Investigators say Audrey Hale fired 152 rounds from start to finish, killing three innocent children and three school employees. The violence horrifying a nation and following these officers home.

utterances.speaker: MATHES
utterances.sentences: There's obviously been loss of sleep, children hugged more than normal.

utterances.speaker: CHIEF JOHN DRAKE, METROPOLITAN NASHVILLE POLICE
utterances.sentences: They believe that their classmate it's going to heaven. That they're in a better place and they're not hurting. The ones that was hurting the most was us.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: And the city of Nashville has actually been receiving letters of condolence from sister cities all across the world. So far they've received them from Iraq, northern Ireland and Magdeburg, Germany. One of these letters right here reads, among the victims are children whose lives still so young were cruelly ended in what was for them a happy place of learning. The citizens of Magdeburg are deeply shocked. Our thoughts are with the families. We wish you and all Nashvillians much strength and fortitude.Guys --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wow, really outpouring, Isabel, from around the world.Thank you for that and bringing us the words of those incredibly brave officers.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: He was silent as he entered and left a plea and left a New York City courtroom, I should say, but he had a lot to say what he got back to Mar-a-Lago in West Palm Beach, Florida. Reactions to former president's primetime speech and how his legal troubles could shape the 2024 race. That's straight ahead.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, joining us now, CNN anchor and correspondent Audie Cornish. She's also the host of the CNN podcast "The Assignment with Audie Cornish." And she joins us now.Good morning. So, there's lots of discuss here. You know, there's a consternation about running the former president's speech or comments live because you know he has -- often has trouble with the truth. But then just his performance in general. What did you think overall of the speech last night, how he handled it?

utterances.speaker: AUDIE CORNISH, CNN ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It's - you can't talk about the speech without talking about the morning, and that those images coming out of the court. There was some conversation that he might talk to the cameras during the arraignment. That did not happen. We've not known him ever to walk away from a camera. So, I think he needed -- he needed to have a corrective moment. He could not end the day on the images that came out and so I think that rally was always going to happen, or some version of it, where he literally could go to a warmer climate politically, literally, figuratively, and have an image at the end of the day that doesn't look like defeat because in those morning kind of court visuals, he -- it was a sobering moment. It was a sobering moment for the country, but clearly for the former president.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Just one more question, as you said, he needed that moment. Those -- that moment last night, does that supersede the images that you are - that -- not in the long -

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I understand your question. I mean if -- Trump has always been a kind of skilled manipulator of some of the basic rules of journalism, which is like, hey, the leader of the free world speaks or this person in power speaks and therefore we must show and air it. That's like our responsibility. And what he can do with those moments is used them for his own ends, right? So, he didn't have a conversation about the issue at hand, and it -- he had kind of a second campaign kickoff. And, you know, we were hearing like the stump speech that incorporated all of his fears about the investigation and his pitch, which will be his picture to the country in 2024, which is, I represent you. An attack on me is an attack on you, and you should spend all of your time focused on me in that endeavor. I mean it's - it's certainly a message.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: It's also a historic moment. For him to - to have the first ever ex-president respond to now being a criminal defendant, I think it's worth hearing what he has to say about it and to see his response, especially the attacks on the judge, after the judge, six hours earlier, had just said, don't be attacking and signaling this out.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Don't do that. Yes. Of course, to your point, he didn't actually react to it, right? He didn't actually say those things. And I think one of the things we're going to have to think about going forward, the media in general, OK, not just the network, is, some of these things that we could fact check, we know he's going to say. You know, we know he's going to make certain comments about the election that he knows are not true. We know he's going to say things about, for instance, this prosecutor that are easily in fact checked. The talking points are consistent and persistent, and I think part of the question will be, if you now have a defendant as a candidate, then there's going to be lots of these opportunities for them to speak in a way that I think might not be so responsible, but it is not their prerogative, right? It's not his job to be responsible. What he's saying publicly, it's his job to defend his innocence. And I think the media is going to have to really think about like how -- how we cover it and there -- there were sort of varying approaches over the last 24 hours.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I think the point -- Sara Matthews, who worked for Trump, her point to Kaitlan last hour was really interesting when Kaitlan said is this a, you know, good, strong platform to run on for 2024? And she said she doesn't think it is because this is about him as much as -- as you pointed out, Kaitlan, he said last night, you know, the word "us." This run, and if this is the strategy, look at these attacks on me. This could happen to you. Like, no. Like, most Americans don't engage in hush money payments, as you were saying, et cetera. It's just -- it's so much about him this time and not as much about us and who he said he was representing in 2016.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: When I said that -- what does the press conference -- does that supersede or whatever -- I forget how exactly I said it, I didn't mean that as a media whether (INAUDIBLE) -

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I mean that, does it wipe out all of those images of him in court and, you know, the pictures of him sitting there in court and the video of him walking.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: No. I mean nothing will obliterate the image of a former president under investigation in the United States.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That was - that was my -

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: It has happened in so many other countries and now we are here. And I think we would have gotten here no matter what given how many investigations are ongoing into this president.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I also think it's important to think about how they're viewing this politically. I was told yesterday he had actually expressed some interest in having his mug shot taken because they realized how they could benefit from that, but notice -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: They put out a fake one, Kaitlan, right?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: They put out a fake one, yes, but no real one. They want - they had expressed interest in that. And as he was speaking last night notice that it says text 88022 Trump to that on the podium in front of him, the lectern in front of him as he's speaking.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I mean they are using this to their advantage just by -

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I mean they've always raised money for his legal troubles.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: This time it actually has to go to them.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, he has a lot of attorneys, but to speak to just his anxiety and his actual anger behind this.Audie, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: It's great talking to you guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you. Good to see you.Don't forget, "The Assignment."

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Audie is wearing a green jacket. I just want to know, Masters are teeing off tomorrow. I don't know if that's a coincident or not.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Ah, hello.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Sports reference.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We called each other.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: You didn't get my text? You're supposed to. That was the plan.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, the question, though, about the Masters is, could it be the last one for five time champion Tiger Woods? He actually just weighed in on that. We'll tell you what he said.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Audie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: When you're playing this course, does it ever cross your mind, this could be the last time?TIGER WOODS, FIVE-TIME MASTERS CHAMPION: Yes, it has. I didn't know -- I mean last year was kind of a - I didn't know if I was going to play again at that time. For some reason, everything kind of came together. I kind of pushed a little bit and I was able to make the cut, which was nice. And, yes, I don't know how many more I have in me. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Tiger Woods hinting that this year's Master may be one of his last.Joining us now to discuss all of this is the sports writer and author of "The Ball in the Air: A Golfing Adventure," Michael Bamberger. Michael, thank you for being here. I mean this is like a - MICHAEL BAMBERGER, AUTHOR, "THE BALL IN THE AIR: A GOLFING ADVENTURE": Good morning. COLLINS: If you're a Tiger Woods fan, and you watched that press conference, did - are you racing to buy your Masters tickets because, you know, the fear that this might be the last time you see Tiger Woods in Augusta?

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: Well, good luck buying your Masters tickets last minute because unless you're on Washington Row (ph) with cash money, that's not going to happen.(LAUGHTER) But, yes, a lot of people -- the Masters tournament, many would know, but some would not, is a four day event. A lot of people want to make sure they're going to be there on Thursday because they're guaranteed that Tiger will play on Thursday. There are people who plot their whole year around the chance to actually glimpse Tiger Woods, the Michael Jordan of golf, play golf. And to -- he'll never play again at the highest level that he played at 20 years ago. But just to see -- to see Tiger Woods in person is an impressive thing. So, I can understand the emotion completely.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'm glad you said that, right, because you don't -- you can still see him in person. You won't get to see him play the great game, which is sad.But, I mean, Michael, you can understand that, as I know I can as a man of a certain age that it doesn't mean that you don't have the passion about what you love, right, about your career and about -- your priorities just change. And perhaps Tiger's at a point in his life where his priorities are just changing.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: Right, Don, his priorities have changed and, of course, they've - the changes have been imposed on him as well. His body has betrayed him. There's been --there's been a lot of psychological warfare going on in his life. He's had a life -- you know, people want to compare them, and I just did, to Michael Jordan. But the American life he probably most resembles in a completely different ways is probably not Michael Jordan, but Michael Jackson, because this guy, Tiger Woods, has had his whole life unfold under the scrutiny of a camera. And as everybody in public life knows, the camera can do a lot for you, but it can -- it comes with a lot of costs as well. So, it has not been an easy life and it shows up in various ways.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You think this is his last?

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: No, it won't be his last. And this particular tournament has a special thing where if you're a former winner, and Tiger Woods has won this tournament five times, you can play basically forever. And Gary Player and Jack Nicholas and others played well into their 70s, if not older.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: So they come back. But they're sort of more - and this is a term of the art, ceremonial players. They're sort of -- it's like -- it's like old timers day at Yankee Stadium. But it was only 2019 where miraculously he won.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: And that might prove to be his last gasp. And if it was, it was a great way to go out.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And, right, Tiger Woods will always be Tiger Woods. I mean, and just -- you know what I mean?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. There you go.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Michael.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Michael, good to see you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Michael.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you for having me here.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What did you want to say? Complete your thought, quickly. We don't want to leave you hanging.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: No, just  like, he's an iconic figure in American life.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERGER
utterances.sentences: And he deserves our consideration I guess is what I'm trying to say.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Michael. Be well.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He said there's a lot of hardware in his leg. He was talking about all the injuries that he's had.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And his car crash and a lot that he's been through.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. And the point that he made about cameras, right, living in front of the cameras, it can be very difficult.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, thank you, Michael.Now our coverage of the former president's indictment continues. We're going to be joined by one of the journalists whose award-winning reporting helped trigger the hush money investigation. (COMMERCIAL BREAK) [06:58:33]

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We're not -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, this is - we're on TV, guys. We're just chatting.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We are on TV and this is happening and Kaitlan and I forgot our hot pink pantsuits.Warner Brothers releasing the second trailer for Greta Gerwig's "Barbie" movie, which stars Margot Robbie and Ryan Gosling.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But, get this, they're not the only Barbie in -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Ah, ah, ah yeah.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Anyway.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Movie.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RYAN GOSLING, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: MARGOT ROBBIE, ACTRESS
utterances.sentences: Hi, Ken.

utterances.speaker: ALEXANDRA SHIPP, ACTRESS
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: EMMA MACKEY, ACTRESS
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: ISSA ARE, AC TRESS
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: SIMU LIU, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: ROBBIE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Ken.

utterances.speaker: LIU
utterances.sentences: Hi, Ken.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That song is going to be stuck in my head. I mean, now, come on Barbie, let's go party.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Barbie girl. Barbie girl.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's an ear - it's an earworm. Well -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Kaitlan really wanted to highlights this, this morning.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: "Barbie" this theaters July 21st. Warner Brothers Discovery is the parent company of CNN.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: it's going to do incredibly well, by the way.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Look, everyone is talking about this movie.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The set looks amazing, actually.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, it does.Want to - want to go together.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's all I got.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This is what I have to say, CNN THIS MORNING continues right now.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
